reasoning:
1. Circle of Competence: I’m loath to buy businesses I don’t fully understand, and Netflix sits at the intersection of content creation, technology platforms, and fierce global competition—outside my circle of competence.  

2. Competitive Moat: While Netflix has shown strong operating margins (32.7% last period), its ROE has never exceeded 15% in any of the last ten years. That tells me pricing power exists, but no enduring moat protects it from Disney+, Amazon, HBO Max and others.  

3. Management & Capital Allocation: Reed Hastings is creative, but funding massive new content with a debt-to-equity ratio near 2.9 is risky. Unlike the disciplined capital allocators at See’s Candies or GEICO, Netflix’s growth comes at the expense of financial leverage.  

4. Financial Health & Consistency: A weak ROE of 4.4%, high debt levels, inconsistent earnings growth and no reliable current ratio data point to a shaky financial foundation. Consistency is the name of the game, and Netflix’s record is spotty.  

5. Valuation vs. Intrinsic Value: My three-stage DCF pegs fair value (with a 15% haircut) at about $854 a share. At current market prices, there’s effectively a –96% margin of safety. Paying double what I believe a business is worth flies in the face of ‘price is what you pay; value is what you get.’  

6. Long-Term Prospects & Red Flags: Streaming economics are subject to subscriber churn, rising content costs and shifting consumer tastes. I don’t see a durable franchise that will prosper for 20 or 30 years.  

7. Comparison to My Portfolio: I’d rather own Coca-Cola or Apple—companies with fortress balance sheets, decades-long moats and capital-allocating management—for similar or better returns. Netflix doesn’t join that company.  

Conclusion: Outside my wheelhouse, overleveraged and pricily valued—my verdict is a clear ‘no.’

fundamental_analysis.details: Weak ROE of 4.4%; High debt to equity ratio of 2.9; Strong operating margins; Current ratio data not available

consistency_analysis.details: Inconsistent earnings growth pattern; Total earnings growth of 1649.3% over past 10 periods

moat_analysis.details: Inconsistent ROE: only 0/10 periods >15%; Strong and stable operating margins (avg: 29.9%) indicate pricing power moat

book_value_analysis.details: Consistent book value per share growth (Buffett's favorite metric)

management_analysis.details: No significant new stock issuance detected; No or minimal dividends paid

details: Using three-stage DCF: Stage 1 (8.0%, 5y), Stage 2 (4.0%, 5y), Terminal (2.5%)
